course_title: Time, Change and Other Aspects of Being

learning_outcomes.description: Acquire an understanding of the perspectives of different philosophical traditions on select metaphysical issues.
Appreciate a selection of in-depth topics in metaphysics and their implications.
Identify, create and develop your own ideas.
Engage in philosophical discussion with others.
Produce a coherent philosophical essay, and present and support your views in an open discussion.

assessments.task_description:
-Essay relating to lectures 2 to 6. See assignment sheet for further details.


-The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.


-A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.weighting: <dd>15% 1.5 points for participation in each tutorial </dd>
assessments.task_description:

The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction

Introduction to course and survey of lectures


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction Introduction to course and survey of lectures

learning_activities.topic:
The reality of time: McTaggart and Nagarjuna

Discuss Mctaggart and Magarjuna's arguments for the non-existence of time. Start to acquire concepts relevant to understanding theories about the nature of time.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: The reality of time: McTaggart and Nagarjuna
learning_activities.topic_description: The reality of time: McTaggart and Nagarjuna Discuss Mctaggart and Magarjuna's arguments for the non-existence of time. Start to acquire concepts relevant to understanding theories about the nature of time.

learning_activities.topic:
The reality of time: McTaggart and Nagarjuna

Tutorial on Heather Dyke, “McTaggart and the Truth about Time”. In Craig Callender (ed.), Time, Reality and Experience. Cambridge University Press. pp. 137-152.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:

An examination of Bergson's views of time and philosophy

learning_activities.topic:
The reality of time: Bergson

Tutorial on Sonja Deppe (2016) “The mind-dependence of the relational structure of time”, Kriterion, Journal of Philosophy, 30(2): 107-124.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: The reality of time: Bergson Tutorial on Sonja Deppe (2016) “The mind-dependence of the relational structure of time”, Kriterion, Journal of Philosophy, 30(2): 107-124.

learning_activities.topic:
The nature of time: eternalism

Lecture on the eternalist view of time - the past, the present and the future all exist.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: The nature of time: eternalism Lecture on the eternalist view of time - the past, the present and the future all exist.

learning_activities.topic:
The nature of time - eternalism

Tutorial on Barry Dainton (2001) “Static Time”, Time and Space, pp. 27-41, Acumen.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: The nature of time - eternalism Tutorial on Barry Dainton (2001) “Static Time”, Time and Space, pp. 27-41, Acumen.

learning_activities.topic:
The nature of time: presentism and growing block

Discuss two views of time: presentism (only the present exists) and the growing block view (the past and the present exist but not the future)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: The nature of time: presentism and growing block
learning_activities.topic_description: The nature of time: presentism and growing block Discuss two views of time: presentism (only the present exists) and the growing block view (the past and the present exist but not the future)

learning_activities.topic:
The nature of time: presentism and the growing block

Tutorial about Ellen Bliss Talbot (1915) “The time-process and the value of human life (part II)”, The Philosophical Review 24(1): 17-36.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: The nature of time: presentism and the growing block

learning_activities.topic:
Absolute idealism

Tutorial on Mary W. Calkins (1919) “The personalistic conception of nature,” The Philosophical Review, 28(2): 115-146. We will only read pp. 122-146.

learning_activities.topic:
Individuals and perspectival realism
